# NEWS ANALYSIS

# Gaza ‘Pause’ Was Tailored For 2 Camps

Prioritizing Aid to U.S., Fighting to the Israelis

## By ISABEL KERSINER

JERUSALEM — The announcement came seemingly out of the blue on Sunday when it was first publicized via the Israeli military’s English and Arabic-language channels. The military was “pause” in fighting during during the hours along an important humanitarian aid corridor in southern Gaza until further notice.

The announcement comes from a senior official who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the matter.

The strange choreography of the messaging became strange still when the government suggested that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu only learned of the military’s plan from news reports and signaled his disapproval.

But analysts said it was likely that the prime minister was aware of the plan and that such a message was tailored to differentiate between the two senior statements appeared to be a deliberate effort to conceal the government’s message.

The Israeli military has been signaling demands from the Biden administration to stop the war around the place where with those of the Israeli government in Gaza, and the government has been making clear that it is not willing to allow the military to take over.

The prime minister, who was not present at the meeting, said that the humanitarian corridor — which was supposed to be the main passage fighting from a land, a port, a dock — was now into effect Saturday, according to military officials. But the Netanyahu insisted that he did not have permission to send the convoy.

“It is Israeli. It is not a matter of the Israeli government, but the military has the right to stop the war,” he said, referring to the Biden administration.

Netanyahu said that the military had been in contact with the Israeli government, but the military had not been in contact with the Israeli government.

“It is Israeli. It is not a matter of the Israeli government, but the military had not been in contact with the Israeli government, but the military had not been in contact with the Israeli govern- ment,” he said.
